Write a summary about 'prehistory'. Limit the output to 150 words. Prehistory refers to the period before written records. It's divided into three eras: Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age. The Stone Age began around 3.3 million years ago with the first use of stone tools by hominids. It's further divided into Paleolithic (Old Stone Age), Mesolithic (Middle Stone Age), and Neolithic (New Stone Age). The Bronze Age (around 3300 BCE) saw the development of metallurgy, while the Iron Age (around 1200 BCE) marked the widespread use of iron tools. Prehistory ended with the invention of writing, which varied by region, ranging from around 3400 BCE in Mesopotamia to the 17th century in some parts of the Americas.

Write a summary about 'prehistory'. Limit the output to 150 words. Prehistory, the period before written records, spans from the dawn of humanity around 2.6 million years ago to the invention of writing, around 3400 BCE. It's divided into three eras: Stone Age (Paleolithic, Mesolithic, Neolithic), Bronze Age, and Iron Age. Humans evolved in Africa, migrated worldwide, and developed tools, languages, and cultures. Major events include the development of agriculture and domestication of animals, leading to settled communities. Art, religion, and complex social structures also emerged. The term 'prehistory' was coined in the 19th century to distinguish it from history, which began with written records.

Write a summary about 'prehistory'. Limit the output to 150 words. Prehistory, the period before written records, spans from the dawn of humanity around 2.6 million years ago to the invention of writing, around 3400 BCE. It's divided into three eras: Stone Age (Paleolithic, Mesolithic, Neolithic), Bronze Age, and Iron Age. Humans evolved in Africa, migrated worldwide, and developed tools, languages, and cultures. Major events include the development of agriculture and domestication of animals, leading to settled communities. Art, religion, and complex social structures also emerged. The term 'prehistory' was coined in the 19th century to distinguish it from history, which began with written records. Prehistory is studied using archaeological methods, as no written records exist. These methods include excavation, analysis of artifacts, and interpretation of physical remains like buildings, tools, and human remains. Prehistory offers valuable insights into human evolution, migration, and cultural development.

Prehistory refers to the period before written records were kept, encompassing the entire human experience up until the invention of writing. It's divided into three eras: Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age. The Stone Age is further segmented into Paleolithic (Old Stone), Mesolithic (Middle Stone), and Neolithic (New Stone). During prehistory, humans evolved from nomadic hunter-gatherers to settled farmers, developing tools, arts, and technologies along the way. Key events include the emergence of Homo sapiens, the spread of humans across the globe, and the advent of agriculture. The transition from prehistory to history occurred independently in several regions, marked by the invention of writing systems around 3400 BCE in Mesopotamia.

It's divided into three eras: the Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age. The Stone Age, lasting until around 3000 BCE, saw early humans as hunter-gatherers using stone tools. The Bronze Age, from 3000 to 1200 BCE, marked advancements in metallurgy and agriculture, leading to the formation of early civilizations. The Iron Age, from 1200 BCE onwards, brought further technological progress, with iron tools replacing bronze ones. Archaeology and anthropology help reconstruct prehistory, shedding light on human evolution, cultures, and societal developments before written records.

Write a summary about 'prehistory'. Limit the output to 150 words. Prehistory is the time period before written records, typically starting from the Big Bang around 13.8 billion years ago and extending until the invention of writing, around 3400 BCE. It's often divided into several eras based on geological and biological changes: Hadean (4.6-3.8 billion years ago), Archaean (3.8-2.5 billion years ago), Proterozoic (2.5 billion-541 million years ago), Cambrian (541-485.4 million years ago), Ordovician (485.4-443.8 million years ago), Silurian (443.8-419.2 million years ago), Devonian (419.2-358.9 million years ago), Carboniferous (358.9-298.9 million years ago), Permian (298.9-251.9 million years ago), Triassic (251.9-201.3 million years ago), Jurassic (201.3-145 million years ago), Cretaceous (145-66 million years ago), Paleogene (66-23.03 million years ago), Neogene (23.03-2.58 million years ago), and Quaternary (2.58 million years ago-present). Key events include the formation of Earth, emergence of life, evolution of multicellular organisms, mass extinctions, and the rise of humans.

This era is divided into three main stages: Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age, based on technological advancements. The Stone Age is further split into Paleolithic (Old Stone Age), Mesolithic (Middle Stone Age), and Neolithic (New Stone Age). Humans during prehistory were hunter-gatherers, developing tools, art, and cultures. The Neolithic period saw the emergence of agriculture and settled communities. The Bronze Age brought metallurgy and further societal advancements, while the Iron Age brought new tools and weapons. Prehistory ended around 3200 BCE when writing was first developed in Mesopotamia.
